title: Garcia's Take: ECP Could Benefit From European Partner; U.S. energy-infrastructure specialist has held talks over a potential investment from Bridgepoint Group
text:
The talks with Energy Capital Partners, also known as ECP, were at an early stage, Bridgepoint added.

ECP is an energy infrastructure-focused investor backing businesses such as power operators, renewable-energy developers and providers of energy-efficiency services. Contrary to the reports, the two firms didn't discuss potential deal prices during their conversations, two people familiar with the matter said.

Europe's clean-energy drive attracted U.S. energy-focused investment firms, including Quantum Energy Partners and Riverstone Holdings, long before Russia's invasion of Ukraine curtailed the region's supply of cheap natural gas and sent local energy prices soaring.

Since the invasion, investment opportunities in Europe's energy-infrastructure sector have expanded as the region struggles to find alternatives to Russia's gas, according to asset managers.

"With a sudden interruption of that cheap and abundant supply, Europe finds itself ill-equipped to make a fast and easy transition to other energy sources," Michele Della Vigna, head of natural resources research at Goldman Sachs Group Inc.'s research group in Europe, said in a recent report.

The world will need $1 trillion in additional annual energy investments over the next five years to ensure energy is available and affordable, he added.

ECP doesn't have offices in Europe, though it has backed at least three investments there. In September, publicly traded Biffa PLC, a waste-management company in England, said it agreed to be acquired for 1.3 billion pounds, equivalent to $1.55 billion, by a new company controlled by ECP.

A potential combination with Bridgepoint would give ECP access to the firm's presence across the region. Bridgepoint has offices in Amsterdam, Frankfurt, London, Madrid and Paris.

ECP's medium size—it has raised $26 billion in capital commitments since it was formed in 2005—and experience with energy infrastructure makes it a potentially attractive target for larger asset managers, many of which are seeking to capitalize on a global shift to clean energy.

Private-equity firms, however, have other ways to expand in Europe, including joint ventures with local investors. ECP could also choose that route.

In any case, ECP appears to see a benefit in expanding beyond North America. Whether it does so with Bridgepoint or another firm remains to be seen.
